attributes.name: Apple Music Sessions: Good Neighbours - Single

editorialNotes.standard:
Indie duo Good Neighbours put their heart and soul into their songs, so when it came to choosing which one to perform for their Apple Music Session, “Ripple” jumped out at Oli Fox and Scott Verrill. “It’s our new song, our new baby,” they tell Apple Music. “We’re very proud of it and it’s nice to finally have it in the world. It was one of the first songs we wrote for the band. And we just wanted to frame it in a new way, so we stripped it down, gave it a mellow vibe and it feels like it’s taken on a new life.” “Ripple” is a song that means a lot to Good Neighbours, so the duo felt it was even more special to give it a new treatment. “The song itself was always quite a deep one for us. It was written about my friend going through grief, and we sort of hid behind the production of this song for quite a while,” say Fox and Verrill. “So it’s nice to let it take on a bit of a new form where the words are at the forefront, and people can hear the message we’re trying to tell them about.” 

For their cover, the boys went for a dreamy version of Gracie Abrams’ “That’s so True” because they think the original is “an absolute belter.” “This song has been everywhere and we can’t escape it,” they say. “But, for once, it’s a song that we actually love and we don’t want to escape. We’re big fans of Gracie Abrams and the album so it’s cool just to put our spin on this tune.” They came up with the new versions while touring across North America with Foster the People during early 2025: “Both of these were made on our bus. And it’s our first time ever doing that. It’s a lot of sleep deprivation that has sparked some creativity within us to do these songs. But it’s been really fun and it’s kind of taken us back to where it all started, doing iPhone recordings of guitars and vocals and doing it that way from scratch. So it’s been super fun and we’re proud of them.”
editorialNotes.short: A mellow take on the duo’s “Ripple,” plus a Gracie Abrams cover.

editorialNotes.standard: Much like his unending devotion for wrestling and sartorial sense of streetwear, Westside Gunn perpetually seeks to put other rappers on. For this spiritual sequel to 2022’s Peace “Fly” God that also technically serves as the 12th installment in his Hermes series, the Griselda impresario once again centers Estee Nack and Stove God Cooks, who collectively and respectively appear on seven of these 11 tracks. Their joint presence on trio cuts “BOSWELL” and the Daringer-produced “VEERT” pushes the fashionably flamboyant FLYGOD back towards coke-rap braggadocio and surrounding themes of luxury amid violence. (Even as his cohorts talk street business, he still fires off a big brag about parallel parking a Bugatti.) The duo moments shine as well, with Stove reminiscing about the recipe with Gunn on “055” and Nack mixing ugly business with filthy pleasure on “BURY ME WITH A STOVE.” A standout presence on 2024’s Still Praying, Brother Tom Sos returns here for two songs in a move that furthers Gunn’s artistic patronage. On “HEALTH SCIENCE,” he moves the proceedings towards something resembling what used to be dubbed conscious rap, while on “GUMBO YAYA” he transforms murderous metaphors into a more principled path. Though better known for his production placements on Mach-Hommy’s #RICHAXXHAITIAN and Conway The Machine’s Slant Face Killah, Elijah Hooks makes an unexpected if rewarding appearance over Conductor Williams’ “DUMP WORLD.” The album’s sole solo joint, “OUTLANDER” allows Gunn to synthesize all of 12’s ideas with his signature WWE nods and the mournful reflections that came to the fore on his preceding 11 EP.
editorialNotes.short: FLYGOD returns with Estee Nack and Stove God Cooks.

editorialNotes.standard: Some people kill their nemeses with kindness; Sabrina Carpenter, the breakout pop star of summer 2024, takes the opposite tack, shooting withering one-liners at loser exes via featherlight melodies, a wink and a smile. The former Disney Channel star began her music career at age 15 with her 2014 debut single “Can’t Blame a Girl for Trying.” Now 25, the singer-songwriter is making the catchiest, funniest, and most honest music of her career at a moment when all the world’s watching. But on songs like “Please Please Please,” on which she begs her boyfriend not to embarrass her (again), she’s poking fun at herself, too. “A lot of what I really love about this album is the accountability,” she tells Apple Music’s Zane Lowe. “I will call myself out just as much as I will call out someone else.” It’s not because Carpenter’s “vertically challenged,” as she puts it, that she named her sixth album Short n’ Sweet. “I thought about some of these relationships, how some of them were the shortest I’ve ever had and they affected me the most,” she tells Lowe. “And I thought about the way that I respond to situations: Sometimes it is very nice, and sometimes it’s not very nice.” Hence songs like “Dumb & Poetic,” a gentle acoustic ballad that’s also a blistering takedown of a guy who masks his sleazy tendencies with therapy buzzwords and a highbrow record collection, or the twangy, hilarious “Slim Pickins,” on which she croons: “Jesus, what’s a girl to do?/This boy doesn’t even know the difference between there, their, and they are/Yet he’s naked in my room.” With good humor and good taste (channeling Rilo Kiley here, Kacey Musgraves there, and on “Sharpest Tool,” a bit of The Postal Service), Carpenter reframes heartbreak through the lens of life’s absurdity. “When you’re at this point in your life where you’re almost at your wits’ end, everything is funny,” Carpenter tells Lowe. “So much of this album was made in the moments where there was something that I just couldn’t stop laughing about. And I was like, well, that might as well just be a whole song.” Carpenter wrote a good deal of the album on an 11-day trip to a tiny town in rural France, where the isolation unlocked her brutally honest side, resulting in unprecedentedly vulnerable music and one song she readily admits shouldn’t work on paper but hits anyway: “Espresso,” the song that catapulted her career with four delightfully strange-sounding words: “That’s that me espresso.” “There really are no rules to the things you say,” she tells Lowe on the songwriting process. “You’re just like, what sounds awesome? What feels awesome? And what gets the story across, whatever story that is?” Still, she’s painted herself in a bit of a corner when it comes to placing an order at coffee shops worldwide: “They’re just waiting for me to say it,” she laughs. “And I’m like, ‘Tea.’”
editorialNotes.short: Still sweet but less short: four new tracks including a Dolly duet.

editorialNotes.standard: In the five years since 2020’s Flores EP, which brought Marca MP such signatures as “Recuerda” and “Tú,” their capacity to produce songs of love and heartache has grown substantially. Though their prowess as a corridos act never abated, as evidenced by 2024’s LEALTAD, the California-based group regularly drops singles focused on matters of the heart. With the slyly titled ONLY ENAMORADOS, a Valentine’s Day offering no less, Chato and his band immerse listeners in more than an hour’s worth of timely tracks. Previously released singles “CADA DÍA TE QUIERO MÁS” and their popular rendition of La Edicion De Culiacan’s “QUÉ BONITA” meet newly recorded versions of apparent favorites like “COSAS RARAS” and “SI YO FUERA LADRÓN.” Some of the other recognizable cover songs arguably hit just as hard as Chato’s early singles, his arrangements and vocals on Tania Dominguez’s “AMOR NO CORRESPONDIDO” and Julio Chaidez’s “EL AMOR EN CARRO” matching the deeply felt sentiments of the existing originals.
editorialNotes.short: A Valentine’s Day 2025 covers set straight from Chato’s heart.

editorialNotes.standard:
Each month, the Apple Music Fitness Mix is helmed by one of dance and electronic music’s best DJs to deliver the perfect set for your next workout. This month’s mix was crafted by none other than Kevin Saunderson, the pioneering DJ and producer who helped draw up the blueprints for Detroit techno in the early ’80s. “I wanted to educate people on really good, strong dance music,” he says. “The theme is: elevate.”

Although Saunderson himself usually turns to the boxing gym for workouts, he says these tracks can motivate you anywhere—especially on a long run where you need an extra boost of momentum. “I envision this mix [helping] people get lost in their workout, whatever it is—pushing them and making them forget that they’re even ‘working out.’” Among his favorite tracks: “Emotions,” a new cut from E-Dancer, Saunderson’s famous underground alias, which he’s recently dusted off and used for a partnership with his son, Dantiez. Also, don’t miss Kid Massive’s “House Music (Move Your Body),” featuring Jim C, which he calls an “outstanding remix full of energy that takes you to another level.”
editorialNotes.short: Put in work with a Detroit techno founding father. “The theme is: elevate.”

editorialNotes.standard: On the cover of $ome $exy $ongs 4 U, we see PARTYNEXTDOOR and Drake tricked out in furry winter gear, posing in front of a pair of buildings that’ll be familiar to anyone who’s ever driven past PND’s hometown of Mississauga, on the western fringe of Toronto. Now, the Absolute World high-rise condos may not be an internationally recognized landmark on par with the CN Tower (which famously graced Drake’s 2016 blockbuster Views), but it’s a fitting visual emblem of the more low-stakes, bringing-it-all-back-home ethos that defines their first full-length collaboration. Even your grandma knows that 2024 was a rough year for Drake, so in that sense, Mississauga represents a proverbial safe space where he can recalibrate and experiment outside the limelight alongside a loyal protégé who’s stood by his side through thick and thin. $ome $exy $ongs 4 U was originally advertised as an EP to be released on Valentine’s Day 2025, but at 21 tracks and 75 minutes, it’s more like getting a gift box of chocolates and discovering there are three more layers underneath. At the outset, the duo’s approach is to pretend 2024 never happened and lean into the singular combination of sensitivity, swagger, and hyper-local referentialism that turned OVO into a rap&B empire in the 2010s. Atmospheric trap tracks like “CN TOWER” and “SOMETHING ABOUT YOU” unfurl like late-night DM threads, taking us inside the fragile psyches of celebrity rappers who pick up their dates in private jets and get them to sign NDAs, yet (as PND testifies on “LASERS”) still get easily triggered when they see an ex-boyfriend’s name tattooed on the back of their neck when they’re doing it doggystyle. The question of whether Drake will use this platform to air out his grievances is settled partway through the album on the pugilistic “GIMME A HUG,” where he comes out swinging at his fair-weather followers, but stops short of getting back in the ring when he declares, “Fuck a rap beef/I’m trying to get the party lit.” And from that point on, he stays true to his word, displaying the charm, humor, and trendspotting savvy that’s made him a star far beyond the rap realm. $ome $exy $ongs 4 U starts to really live up to its title with the playful Spanglish seduction of “MEET YOUR PADRE,” a collaboration with urban sierreño star Chino Pacas that sounds like a regional-Mexican spin on “One Dance,” while the delirious “NOKIA” sees Drake and PND dropping rhymes over shapeshifting ’80s-electro beats like an OVO Outkast. But perhaps the biggest surprise arrives in the form of “DIE TRYING,” an irresistibly melodic, countrified confessional that’s of a piece with acoustic alt-pop anthems like Post Malone’s “Circles” and Clairo’s “Bags”—and which suggests the most effective way to move beyond a rap beef is to move beyond rap entirely.
editorialNotes.short: The OVO power duo’s epic “EP” is as surprising as it is sprawling.
One of the most innovative hip-hop artists in the business.
Cara articulated the conflicted moods of youth with clarity and poise.
